<span id = "number">1</span><title>一</title>	<p>In Chinese characters、 the number one is laid on its side、 unlike the Roman numeral i which stands upright。 As you would expect、 it is written from left to right。 一  As a primitive element、 the key－word meaning is discarded、 since it is...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一 いち">イチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一 いつ">イツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一ひと">一ひと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一ひと－つ">一ひと－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/一">一</a>
<span id = "number">2</span><title>二</title>	<p>Like the Roman numeral ii、 which reduplicates the numeral i、 the kanji for two is a simple reduplication of the horizontal stroke that means one。 The order of writing goes from above to below、 with the first stroke slightly shorter。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二 に">ニ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二ふた">二ふた</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二ふた－つ">二ふた－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/二">二</a>
<span id = "number">3</span><title>三</title>	<p>And like the Roman numeral iii、 which triples the numeral i、 the kanji for three simply triples the single horizontal stroke。 In writing it、 think of “1 ＋ 2 ＝ 3” （一 ＋ 二 ＝ 三 ） in order to keep the middle stroke shorter。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三 さん">サン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三み">三み</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三み－つ">三み－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三みっ－つ">三みっ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/三">三</a>
<span id = "number">4</span><title>四</title>	<p>This kanji is composed of two primitive elements、 mouth 口 and human legs 乳、 both of which we will meet in the coming lessons。 Assuming that you already knew how to write this kanji、 we will pass over the “story” connected with it until la...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四 し">シ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四よ">四よ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四よ－つ">四よ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四よっ－つ">四よっ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四よん">四よん</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/四">四</a>
<span id = "number">5</span><title>五</title>	<p>As with four、 we shall postpone learning the primitive elements that make up this character。 Note how the general principle we just learned in the preceding frame applies to the writing of the character for five。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五 ご">ゴ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五いつ">五いつ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五いつ－つ">五いつ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/五">五</a>
<span id = "number">6</span><title>六</title>	<p>The primitives here are top hat and animal legs。 Once again、 we glide over them until later。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六 ろく">ロク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六む">六む</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六む－つ">六む－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六むっ－つ">六むっ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六むい">六むい</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/六">六</a>
<span id = "number">7</span><title>七</title>	<p>Note that the first stroke “cuts” through the second。 This distinguishes seven from the character for spoon 匕 （frame 444 匕）、 in which the horizontal stroke stops short。  As a primitive、 this form takes on the meaning of diced、 i。e...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七 しち">シチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七なな">七なな</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七なな－つ">七なな－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七なの">七なの</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/七">七</a>
<span id = "number">8</span><title>八</title>	<p>Just as the Arabic numeral “8” is composed of a small circle followed by a larger one、 so the kanji for eight is composed of a short line followed by a longer line、 slanting towards it but not touching it。 And just as the “lazy 8” ∞ is th...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八 はち">ハチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八や">八や</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八や－つ">八や－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八やっ－つ">八やっ－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八よう">八よう</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/八">八</a>
<span id = "number">9</span><title>九</title>	<p>If you take care to remember the stroke order of this kanji、 you will not have trouble later keeping it distinct from the kanji for power 力 （frame 858 力）。  As a primitive、 we shall use this kanji to mean baseball team or simply baseball。 ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九 きゅう">キュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九 く">ク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九ここの">九ここの</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九ここの－つ">九ここの－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/九">九</a>
<span id = "number">10</span><title>十</title>	<p>Turn this character 45º either way and you have the x used for the Roman numeral ten。  As a primitive、 this character sometimes keeps its meaning of ten and sometimes signifies needle、 this latter derived from the kanji for needle 針 （frame 274...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十 じゅう">ジュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十 じっ">ジッ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十とお">十とお</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十と">十と</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/十">十</a>
<span id = "number">11</span><title>口</title>	<p>Like several of the first characters we shall learn、 the kanji for mouth is a clear pictograph。 Since there are no circular shapes in the kanji、 the square must be used to depict the circle。  As a primitive、 this form also means mouth。 Any of...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口 く">ク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口くち">口くち</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/口">口</a>
<span id = "number">12</span><title>日</title>	<p>This kanji is intended to be a pictograph of the sun。 Recalling what we said in the previous frame about round forms、 it is easy to detect the circle and the big smile that characterize our simplest drawings of the sun—like those yellow badges with...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日 にち">ニチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日 じつ">ジツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日ひ">日ひ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日か">日か</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/日">日</a>
<span id = "number">13</span><title>月</title>	<p>This character is actually a picture of the moon、 with the two horizontal lines representing the left eye and mouth of the mythical “man in the moon。” （Actually、 the Japanese see a hare in the moon、 but it is a little farfetched to find one...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月 げつ">ゲツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月 がつ">ガツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月つき">月つき</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/月">月</a>
<span id = "number">14</span><title>田</title>	<p>Another pictograph、 this kanji looks like a bird’s－eye view of a rice field divided into four plots。 Be careful when writing this character to get the order of the strokes correct。 You will find that it follows perfectly the principle stated in...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田 でん">デン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田た">田た</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/田">田</a>
<span id = "number">15</span><title>目</title>	<p>Here again、 if we round out the corners of this kanji and curve the middle strokes upwards and downwards respectively、 we get something resembling an eye。  As a primitive、 the kanji keeps its sense of eye、 or to be more specific、 an eyeball...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目 もく">モク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目 ぼく">ボク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目め">目め</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目ま">目ま</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/目">目</a>
<span id = "number">16</span><title>古</title>	<p>The primitive elements that compose this character are ten and mouth、 but you may find it easier to remember it as a pictograph of a tombstone with a cross on top。 Just think back to one of those graveyards you have visited、 or better still、 used...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古 こ">コ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古ふる－い">古ふる－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古ふる－す">古ふる－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/古">古</a>
<span id = "number">17</span><title>吾</title>	<p>There are a number of kanji for the word I、 but the others tend to be more specific than this one。 The key word here should be taken in the general psychological sense of the “perceiving subject。” Now the one place in our bodies that all five s...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾 あ archaic">あ archaic</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾 ご archaic">ご archaic</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾われ archaic 我">吾われ archaic 我</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾吾れ archaic 我が">吾吾れ archaic 我が</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吾">吾</a>
<span id = "number">18</span><title>冒</title>	<p>Remember when you were young and your mother told you never to look directly into the sun for fear you might burn out your eyes？ Probably you were foolish enough to risk a quick glance once or twice； but just as probably、 you passed that bit of fol...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒 ぼう">ボウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒おか－す">冒おか－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冒">冒</a>
<span id = "number">19</span><title>朋</title>	<p>The first companion that God made、 as the Bible story goes、 was Eve。 Upon seeing her、 Adam exclaimed、 “Flesh of my flesh！” And that is precisely what this kanji says in so many strokes。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朋">朋</a>

<span id = "number">21</span><title>唱</title>	<p>This one is easy！ You have one mouth making no noise （the choirmaster） and two mouths with wagging tongues （the minimum for a chorus）。 So think of the key word、 chant、 as monastery singing and the kanji is yours forever （see frame 11 ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱とな－える">唱とな－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唱">唱</a>

<span id = "number">33</span><title>凹</title>	<p>You couldn’t have asked for a better key word for this kanji！ Just have a look at it： a perfect image of a concave lens （remembering、 of course、 that the kanji square off rounded things）、 complete with its own little “cave。” Now all...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹 おう">オウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凹">凹</a>
<span id = "number">34</span><title>凸</title>	<p>Maybe this helps you see how the Japanese have no trouble keeping convex distinct from concave。 Note the odd feeling of the third stroke。 If it doesn’t feel all that strange now、 by the time you are done with this book、 it will。 There are ver...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸 とつ">トツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凸">凸</a>
<span id = "number">35</span><title>旧</title>	<p>A walking stick is needed for days of olden times、 since days、 too、 get old—at least insofar as we refer to them as the “good old days。” The main thing here is to think of “good old days” when you hear the key word olden times。 The re...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧 きゅう">キュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旧">旧</a>
<span id = "number">36</span><title>自</title>	<p>You can think of this kanji as a stylized pictograph of the nose、 that little drop that Mother Nature set between your eyes。 The Jap anese refer to themselves by pointing a finger at their nose— giving us an easy way to remember the kanji for onese...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自 じ">ジ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自 し">シ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自みずか－ら">自みずか－ら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/自">自</a>
<span id = "number">37</span><title>白</title>	<p>The color white is a mixture of all the primary colors、 both for pigments and for light、 as we see when a prism breaks up the rays of the sun。 Hence、 a single drop of sun spells white。  As a primitive、 this character can either retain its mea...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白 はく">ハク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白 びゃく">ビャク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白しろ">白しろ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白しら">白しら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白しろ－い">白しろ－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/白">白</a>
<span id = "number">38</span><title>百</title>	<p>The Japanese refer to a person’s 99th birthday as a “white year” because white is the kanji you are left with if you subtract one from a hundred。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百 ひゃく">ヒャク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/百">百</a>
<span id = "number">39</span><title>中</title>	<p>The elements here are a walking stick and a mouth。 Remember the trouble your mother had getting medicine in your mouth？ Chances are it crossed her mind more than once to grab something handy、 like your grandfather’s walking stick、 to pry open y...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中 ちゅう">チュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中 じゅう">ジュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中なか">中なか</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/中">中</a>
<span id = "number">40</span><title>千</title>	<p>This kanji is almost too simple to pull apart、 but for the sake of practice、 have a look at the drop above and the ten below。 Now put the elements together by thinking of squeezing two more zeros out of an eyedropper alongside the number ten to mak...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千ち">千ち</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/千">千</a>
<span id = "number">41</span><title>舌</title>	<p>The primitive for mouth and the character for thousand naturally form the idea of tongue if one thinks of a thousand mouths able to speak the same language、 or as we say、 “sharing a common tongue。” It is easy to see the connection between the i...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌 ぜつ">ゼツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌した">舌した</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舌">舌</a>
<span id = "number">42</span><title>升</title>	<p>This is the character for the little wooden box that the Japanese use for measuring things、 as well as for drinking saké out of。 Simply imagine the outside as spiked with a thousand sharp needles、 and the quaint little measuring box becomes a drin...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升ます">升ます</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/升">升</a>
<span id = "number">43</span><title>昇</title>	<p>Our image here is made up of two primitive elements： a sun and a measuring box。 Just as the sun can be seen rising up in the morning from—where else—the Land of the Rising Sun、 this kanji has the sun rising up out of a Japanese measuring box—...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇のぼ－る">昇のぼ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昇">昇</a>
<span id = "number">44</span><title>丸</title>	<p>We speak of “round numbers、” or “rounding a number off 、” meaning to add an insignificant amount to bring it to the nearest 10。 For instance、 if you add just a wee bit、 the tiniest drop、 to nine、 you end up with a round number。  A...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸 がん">ガン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸まる">丸まる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸まる－い">丸まる－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸まる－める">丸まる－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丸">丸</a>
<span id = "number">45</span><title>寸</title>	<p>This kanji actually stood for a small measurement used prior to the metric system、 a bit over an inch in length、 and from there acquired the sense of measurement。 In the old system、 it was one－tenth of a shaku （whose kanji we shall meet in fr...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸 すん">スン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寸">寸</a>
<span id = "number">46</span><title>専</title>	<p>Ten 。 。 。 rice fields 。 。 。 glue。 That is how one would read the primitive elements of this kanji from top to bottom。 Now if we make a simple sentence out of these elements、 we get： “Ten rice fields glued together。” A specialty...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専もっぱ－ら">専もっぱ－ら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/専">専</a>
<span id = "number">47</span><title>博</title>	<p>At the left we have the needle； at the right、 the kanji for specialty、 plus an extra drop at the top。 Think of a Dr。 who is a specialist with a needle （an acupuncturist） and let the drop at the top represent the period at the end of Dr。 I...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博 はく">ハク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博 ばく">バク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/博">博</a>
<span id = "number">48</span><title>占</title>	<p> This is one of those kanji that is a real joy of simplicity： a divining rod with a mouth—which translate directly into fortunetelling。 Note how the movement from top to bottom （the movement in which the kanji are written） is also the order of ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占し－める">占し－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占うらな－う">占うらな－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/占">占</a>
<span id = "number">49</span><title>上</title>	<p>The two directions、 above and below、 are usually pointed at with the finger。 But the characters do not follow that custom、 so we have to choose something else、 easily remembered。 The prim－ itives show a magic wand standing above a —“mag...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上 じょう">ジョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上うえ">上うえ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上うわ">上うわ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上かみ">上かみ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上あ－げる">上あ－げる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上あ－がる">上あ－がる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上のぼ－る">上のぼ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上のぼ－せる">上のぼ－せる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上のぼ－す">上のぼ－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上">上</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/上">上</a>
<span id = "number">50</span><title>下</title>	<p>Here we see our famous miraculous magic wand hanging、 all on its own、 below the ceiling、 as you probably already guessed would happen。 In addition to giving us two new kanji、 the two shapes given in this and the preceding frame also serve to fi...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下 か">カ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下 げ">ゲ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下した">下した</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下しも">下しも</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下もと">下もと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下さ－げる">下さ－げる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下さ－がる">下さ－がる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下くだ－る">下くだ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下くだ－す">下くだ－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下くだ－さる">下くだ－さる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下お－ろす">下お－ろす</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/下お－りる">下お－りる</a>
<span id = "number">51</span><title>卓</title>	<p>The word eminent suggests a famous or well－known person。 So all you need to do—given the primitives of a magic wand and a sunflower—is to think of the world’s most eminent magician as one who uses a sunflower for a magic wand （like a flower...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓 たく">タク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/卓">卓</a>
<span id = "number">52</span><title>朝</title>	<p>On the right we see the moon fading off into the first light of morning、 and to the left 、 the mist that falls to give nature a shower to prepare it for the coming heat。 If you can think of the moon tilting over to spill mist on your garden、 you ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝あさ">朝あさ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朝">朝</a>
<span id = "number">53</span><title>只</title>	<p>When we run across abstract key words like this one、 the best way to get an image it to recall some common but suggestive phrase in which the word appears。 For instance、 we can think of the expression “it’s the only one of its kind。” Then w...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/只">只</a>
<span id = "number">54</span><title>貝</title>	<p>To remember the primitive elements that make up this kanji、 an eye and animal legs、 you might be tempted to think of it as a pictograph of a shellfish with its ridged shell at the top and two little legs sticking out of the bottom。 But that might n...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝かい">貝かい</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貝">貝</a>
<span id = "number">55</span><title>貞</title>	<p>Now take the last primitive、 the shellfish、 and set a magic wand over it、 and you have the kanji for upright。 After all、 the clam and the oyster are incapable of walking upright。 It would take a magician with his wand to pull off such a feat...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞 てい">テイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貞">貞</a>
<span id = "number">56</span><title>員</title>	<p>How do we get a mouth over a shellfish to mean an employee？ Simple。 Just remember the advice new employees get about keeping their mouths shut and doing their job、 and then make that more graphic by picturing an office building full of whitecollar ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員 いん">イン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/員">員</a>
<span id = "number">57</span><title>見</title>	<p>The elements that compose the character for see are the eye firmly fixed to a pair of human legs。 Surely、 somewhere in your experience、 there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up to help you remember this character…。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見 けん">ケン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見み－る">見み－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見み－える">見み－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見み－せる">見み－せる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/見">見</a>
