<span id = "number">59</span><title>元</title>	<p>“In the beginning…” starts that marvelous shelf of books we call the Bible。 It talks about how all things were made、 and tells us that when the Creator came to humanity she made two of them、 man and woman。 While we presume she made two of e...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元 げん">ゲン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元 がん">ガン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元もと">元もと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/元">元</a>
<span id = "number">60</span><title>頁</title>	<p>What we have to do here is turn a shellfish into a page of a book。 The one at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book、 in fact a book of only one page。 Imagine a title printed on the shell of an oyster、 let us say “Pearl of Wisdom...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頁">頁</a>
<span id = "number">61</span><title>頑</title>	<p>This character refers to the blockheaded、 persistent stubbornness of one who sticks to an idea or a plan just the way it was at the beginning、 without letting anything that comes up along the way alter things in the least。 The explanation makes “...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑 がん">ガン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頑">頑</a>
<span id = "number">62</span><title>凡</title>	<p>While we refer to something insignificant as a “drop in the bucket、” the kanji for mediocre suggests the image of a “drop in the wind。”</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡 ぼん">ボン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡 はん">ハン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/凡">凡</a>
<span id = "number">63</span><title>負</title>	<p>Above we have the condensed form of bound up、 and below the familiar shellfish。 Now imagine two oysters engaged in shell－toshell combat、 the one who is defeated being bound and gagged with seaweed、 the victor towering triumphantly over it。 Th...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負 ふ">フ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負ま－ける">負ま－ける</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負ま－かす">負ま－かす</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負お－う">負お－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/負">負</a>
<span id = "number">64</span><title>万</title>	<p>Japanese counts higher numbers in units of ten thousand、 unlike the West、 which advances according to units of one thousand。 （Thus、 for instance、 40、000 would be read “four ten－thousands” by a Japanese。） Given that the comma is us...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万 まん">マン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万 ばん">バン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/万">万</a>
<span id = "number">65</span><title>句</title>	<p>By combining the two primitives bound up and mouth、 it is easy to see how this character can get the meaning of a phrase。 After all、 a phrase is nothing more than a number of words bound up tightly and neatly so that they will fit in your mouth。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句 く">ク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/句">句</a>
<span id = "number">66</span><title>肌</title>	<p>Ever notice how the texture of your face and hands is aff ected by the wind？ A day’s skiing or sailing makes them rough and dry、 and in need of a good soft cream to soothe the burn。 So whenever a part of the body gets exposed to the wind、 its t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌はだ">肌はだ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肌">肌</a>
<span id = "number">67</span><title>旬</title>	<p>There simply is not a good phrase in English for the block of ten days which this character represents。 So we resurrect the classical phrase、 decameron、 whose connotations the tales of Boccaccio have done much to enrich。 Actually、 it refers to ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬 じゅん">ジュン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬 しゅん">シュン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/旬">旬</a>
<span id = "number">68</span><title>勺</title>	<p>If you want to bind up drops of anything—water、 soup、 lemonade—you use something to scoop these drops up、 which is what we call a ladle。 See the last drop left inside the ladle？</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勺">勺</a>
<span id = "number">69</span><title>的</title>	<p>The elements white bird and ladle easily suggest the image of a bull’s eye if you imagine a rusty old ladle with a bull’s eye painted on it in the form of a tiny white bird、 who lets out a little “peep” every time you hit the target。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的 てき">テキ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的まと">的まと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/的">的</a>
<span id = "number">70</span><title>首</title>	<p>Reading this kanji from the top down、 we have： horns 。 。 。 nose。 Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose－head hanging on the den wall、 with its great horns and long nose。 Now while we would speak of cutting off a moose’s ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首 しゅ">シュ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首くび">首くび</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/首">首</a>
<span id = "number">71</span><title>乙</title>	<p>The kanji shown here actually represents the “second” position in the old Chinese zodiac、 which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration、 much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals。 Among its many other meanin...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙 おつ">オツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乙">乙</a>
<span id = "number">72</span><title>乱</title>	<p>In a riot、 manners are laid aside and tempers get short、 even in so courtesy－conscious a land as Japan。 This kanji shows what happens to a rioting tongue： it gets “barbed” like a fishhook、 and sets to attacking the opposition、 to hook t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱 らん">ラン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱みだ－れる">乱みだ－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱みだ－す">乱みだ－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乱">乱</a>
<span id = "number">73</span><title>直</title>	<p>Begin with the top two primitives、 needle and eye。 Together they represent the eye of a needle。 Below them is a fishhook that has been straightened out and its barb removed so that it can pass through the eye of the needle。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直 ちょく">チョク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直 じき">ジキ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直ただ－ちに">直ただ－ちに</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直なお－す">直なお－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直なお－る">直なお－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/直">直</a>
<span id = "number">74</span><title>具</title>	<p>Here is the full kanji on which the last frame is based。 If you can think of a table full of carpenter’s tools of all sorts、 each equipped with its own eye so that it can keep a watch over what you are doing with it、 you won’t have trouble late...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具 ぐ">グ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/具">具</a>
<span id = "number">75</span><title>真</title>	<p>Here again we meet the composite element、 eye of the needle、 which here combines with tool to give us a measure of what is true and what is not。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真 しん">シン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真ま">真ま</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/真">真</a>
<span id = "number">76</span><title>工</title>	<p>The pictograph of an I beam、 like the kind that is used in heavy construction work on buildings and bridges、 gives us the character for craft in general。  As a primitive element、 the key word retains the meaning of craft and also takes on the rel...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工 く">ク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/工">工</a>
<span id = "number">77</span><title>左</title>	<p>By combining the primitive and the kanji of the last two frames and reading the results、 we get： by one’s side 。 。 。 craft。 Conveniently、 the left has traditionally been considered the “sinister” side、 where dark and occult crafts a...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左 さ">サ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左ひだり">左ひだり</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/左">左</a>
<span id = "number">78</span><title>右</title>	<p>When thinking of the key word right、 in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame、 take advantage of the doublemeaning here、 too。 Imagine a little mouth hanging down by your side—like a little voice of conscience—telling you the right ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 う">ウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 ゆう">ユウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右みぎ">右みぎ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右">右</a>
<span id = "number">79</span><title>有</title>	<p>The picture here is of someone with a slab of meat dangling by the side、 perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist。 Think of it as an evil spirit in possession of one’s soul、 who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh meat to hang by one...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 ゆう">ユウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 う">ウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有あ－る">有あ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有">有</a>
<span id = "number">80</span><title>賄</title>	<p>To the left we have the primitive for a shellfish、 and to the right the kanji we just learned for possess。 Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word possess、 and now expand your image of shells to include the ancient value they had as mon...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄 わい">ワイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄まかな－う">賄まかな－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄">賄</a>
<span id = "number">81</span><title>貢</title>	<p>A tribute has a kind of double－meaning in English： honor paid freely and money collected by coercion。 Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard－earned money。 Litt...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 く">ク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢みつ－ぐ">貢みつ－ぐ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢">貢</a>
<span id = "number">82</span><title>項</title>	<p>To the right we see a head and to the left an element that means craft。 When we think of a paragraph、 we immediately think of a heading device to break a text into parts。 （Think of the elaborate heads often seen at the start of medieval manuscrip...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項">項</a>
<span id = "number">83</span><title>刀</title>	<p>Although this kanji no longer looks very much like a sword、 it does have some resemblance to the handle of the sword。 This is to our advantage、 in that it helps us make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji。 In the form...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 とう">トウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀かたな">刀かたな</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀">刀</a>
<span id = "number">84</span><title>刃</title>	<p>Think of using a dagger as a razor blade、 and it shouldn’t be hard to imagine cutting yourself。 See the little drop of blood clinging to the blade？</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 じん">ジン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃は">刃は</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃">刃</a>
<span id = "number">85</span><title>切</title>	<p>To the right we see the dagger and next to it the number seven whose primitive meaning we decided would be diced （frame 7 七 ）。 It is hard to think of cutting anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs。 Only let...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 せつ">セツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 さい">サイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切き－る">切き－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切き－れる">切き－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切">切</a>
<span id = "number">86</span><title>召</title>	<p>A sword or dagger posed over a mouth is how the character for “beckoning” is written。 The related but less tame key word seduce was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the—how shall we put it？—Freudian implications of the kanji。 （...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召め－す">召め－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召">召</a>
<span id = "number">87</span><title>昭</title>	<p>Let the key word suggest shining one’s shoes、 the purpose of which is to seduce the sun down on them for all to see。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭">昭</a>
<span id = "number">88</span><title>則</title>	<p>The character depicts a clam alongside a great and flashing saber。 Think of digging for clams in an area where there are gaming rules governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it。 So you take your trusty saber、 which you have careful...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則 そく">ソク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則">則</a>
<span id = "number">89</span><title>副</title>	<p>The key word vice has the sense of someone second－in－command。 The great and flashing saber to the right （its usual location、 so you need not worry about where to put it from now on） and the wealth on the left combine to create an image of div...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副 ふく">フク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副">副</a>
<span id = "number">90</span><title>別</title>	<p>In the Old East、 the samurai and his saber were never separated。 They were constant companions、 like the cowboy of the Old West and his six－shooter。 This character depicts what must have been the height of separation－anxiety for a samurai： ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別 べつ">ベツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別わか－れる">別わか－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別">別</a>
<span id = "number">91</span><title>丁</title>	<p>The picture here is of a street sign on a long pole： Hollywood and Vine、 if you please、 or any street that immediately conjures up the image of a street sign to you。  Used as a primitive、 we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 てい">テイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁">丁</a>
<span id = "number">92</span><title>町</title>	<p>Street signs standing at the corner of the rice fields depict the village limits。 （Remember what was said earlier： when used as a primitive、 a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word。）</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町まち">町まち</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町">町</a>
<span id = "number">93</span><title>可</title>	<p>Remember the story about the “Little Engine that Could” when you hear this key word、 and the rest is simple。 See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain—”I think I can、 I think I can。。。”—spitting railr...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可 か">カ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可">可</a>
<span id = "number">94</span><title>頂</title>	<p>The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning “humble acceptance。” Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing、 we have： nail 。 。 。 head。 As in “hitting the nail on the head。” Now one presumes that mo...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂いただ－く">頂いただ－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂いただき">頂いただき</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂">頂</a>
<span id = "number">95</span><title>子</title>	<p>This kanji is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young children who cannot get around by themselves。 The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air； the s...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 し">シ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 す">ス</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子こ">子こ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子">子</a>

<span id = "number">97</span><title>了</title>	<p>Learn this character by returning to frame 95 子 and the image given there。 The only diff erence is that the “arms” have been left off （actually、 only tucked inside）。 Thus a child with its arms wrapped up into the back－sack is the pictur...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了 りょう">リョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了">了</a>
<span id = "number">98</span><title>女</title>	<p>You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting woman drawn behind this character、 with two legs at the bottom、 two arms （the horizontal line） and the head poking out the top。 A little farfetched、 until you draw the character and fee...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 じょ">ジョ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 にょ">ニョ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 にょう">ニョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女おんな">女おんな</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女め">女め</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女">女</a>
<span id = "number">99</span><title>好</title>	<p>The phrase “to be fond of someone” has a natural gentleness about it、 and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giv－ ing us the related term “to fondle。” The character likens it to a woman fondling her child。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好この－む">好この－む</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好す－く">好す－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好">好</a>

<span id = "number">101</span><title>母</title>	<p>Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for woman in it、 the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a mama。 Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother’s breast...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 ぼ">ボ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母はは">母はは</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母">母</a>
<span id = "number">102</span><title>貫</title>	<p>If one is asked to think of associations for the word pierce、 among the first to come to mind is that of piercing one’s ears to hold earrings、 a quite primitive form of self－mutilation that has survived into the 21st century。 The kanji here is ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫 かん">カン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫つらぬ－く">貫つらぬ－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫">貫</a>

<span id = "number">105</span><title>小</title>	<p>The sense of little in this character is not the same as “a little bit。” That meaning comes in the next frame。 Here little means “small” or “tiny。” The image is one of three little drops、 the first of which （the one in the middle）...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小ちい－さい">小ちい－さい</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小こ">小こ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小お">小お</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小">小</a>

<span id = "number">113</span><title>石</title>	<p>With a mouth under a cliff、 what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern、 before which a great stone has been rolled so that none may enter。 Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 せき">セキ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 しゃく">シャク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 こく">コク</a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石いし">石いし</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石">石</a>
<span id = "number">114</span><title>肖</title>	<p>The word resemblance should suggest、 among other things、 a son’s resemblance to his father。 A “chip off the old block” is the way we often put it、 but the character is more simple。 It speaks of a little bit of flesh。  When used as a pri...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖">肖</a>

<span id = "number">116</span><title>砕</title>	<p>We begin with the two elements on the right、 baseball and needle。 Since they will be coming together from time to time、 let us give the two of them the sense of a game of cricket in which a needle is laid across the wicket。 Then imagine using a r...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕 さい">サイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕くだ－く">砕くだ－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕くだ－ける">砕くだ－ける</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕">砕</a>
<span id = "number">117</span><title>砂</title>	<p>Good sand for beaches has few or no stones in it。 That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don’t have to watch our step as we cavort about。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 さ">サ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 しゃ">シャ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂すな">砂すな</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂">砂</a>

<span id = "number">127</span><title>川</title>	<p>We have taken the image of a river stream over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines、 or ripple along in lines。 All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here、 a pictograph of a stream。  As a primitive、 this...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川かわ">川かわ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川">川</a>

<span id = "number">129</span><title>順</title>	<p>In primitive language、 this character would read stream 。 。 。 head。 And that turns out to be convenient for remembering its meaning of obey。 Either one obeys the person who is head of an organization or else obeys by following the stream of o...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順 じゅん">ジュン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順">順</a>
<span id = "number">130</span><title>水</title>	<p>This character、 which looks a bit like a snowflake、 is actually a pictograph of water—not any particular body of water or movement of water、 but simply the generic name for water。 Should you have any difficulty remembering it、 simply think of...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 すい">スイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水みず">水みず</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水">水</a>
<span id = "number">131</span><title>氷</title>	<p>The appearance of the primitive for water in its full form tells us that we have something to do with water here。 The extra drop to the left 、 added as a second stroke、 changes the picture from a splash caused by a walking stick dropped into water ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 ひょう">ヒョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷こおり">氷こおり</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷ひ">氷ひ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷">氷</a>
<span id = "number">132</span><title>永</title>	<p>This kanji also uses the full form of water、 though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with water。 Remember what William Blake said about seeing “infinity in a grain of sand and eternity in an hour”？ Well、 reading this character f...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永 えい">エイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永なが－い">永なが－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永">永</a>
<span id = "number">133</span><title>泉</title>	<p>Call to mind the image of a fresh、 bubbling spring of water、 and you will probably notice how the top of the spring you are thinking of、 the part where the “bubbling” goes on、 is all white。 Happily、 the white is just where it should be、...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉いずみ">泉いずみ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉">泉</a>
<span id = "number">134</span><title>原</title>	<p>Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings、 the meadow you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain meadow in the Austrian Alps。 （Perhaps the opening scene of “The Sound of Music” will help。） Simply think of...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 げん">ゲン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原はら">原はら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原">原</a>
<span id = "number">135</span><title>願</title>	<p>A meadow and a head are all we are given to work with in the kanji for petition。 Since the key word already suggests something like a formal request made of some higher power、 let us imagine a gigantic Wizard－of－Oz head located in the middle of t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願 がん">ガン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願ねが－う">願ねが－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願">願</a>
<span id = "number">136</span><title>泳</title>	<p>The primitive to the left 、 you will recall from frame 130 水、 represents water。 To the right、 we see the kanji for eternity。 Knowing how much children like swimming、 what could be a better image of eternal bliss than an endless expanse of w...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳 えい">エイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳およ－ぐ">泳およ－ぐ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳">泳</a>
<span id = "number">137</span><title>沼</title>	<p>Unlike the meadow with its cliff s、 the marshlands are low and near a source of water that feeds them until they get soggy through and through。 Why certain land becomes marshy is probably due to the fact that it felt thirsty、 and so tried its best ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼ぬま">沼ぬま</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼">沼</a>
<span id = "number">138</span><title>沖</title>	<p>This kanji could hardly be simpler。 The key word open sea readily suggests being out in the middle of a great body of water。 Thinking of it in this way should avoid confusion with the kanji for “open、” which we will meet later on。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 ちゅう">チュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖おき">沖おき</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖">沖</a>
<span id = "number">139</span><title>江</title>	<p>Unlike the river、 the ocean、 the lake、 and the pond、 the creek is often no more then a dribble of water trickling down a small gully。 While the geological history of the larger bodies of water is hard to surmise sometimes、 all of us know from...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江え">江え</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江">江</a>
<span id = "number">140</span><title>汁</title>	<p>To make soup、 one begins with water and then starts adding things to it、 often left overs from the icebox。 This is how the thick soup or stew called “seven－in－one” is made。 This kanji does it three better、 giving us a ten－ingredient s...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 じゅう">ジュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁しる">汁しる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁">汁</a>
<span id = "number">141</span><title>潮</title>	<p>Before we get to explaining this character、 take a look at it and see if you can figure out the primitive elements on your own…。 On the left is the water—that much is easy。 On the right we have only one primitive、 the kanji for morning learne...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮しお">潮しお</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮">潮</a>
<span id = "number">142</span><title>源</title>	<p>With the advice of the last frame in mind、 it is easy to see water and meadow in this character for source。 Both in its etymology （it has a common parent with the word “surge”） and in popular usage、 source suggests the place water comes fro...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 げん">ゲン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源みなもと">源みなもと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源">源</a>
<span id = "number">143</span><title>活</title>	<p>When we speak of a lively personality or a lively party、 we immediately think of a lot of chatter。 This kanji depicts the idea of lively by having tongues babble and splash around like flowing water。 </p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活 かつ">カツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活">活</a>
<span id = "number">144</span><title>消</title>	<p>Among the many things water is useful for is extinguishing fires、 and that is just what we have here。 First of all、 take the water at the left as the drops of water that are used to depict water in general。 In the best of all possible worlds、 t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消き－える">消き－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消け－す">消け－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消">消</a>
<span id = "number">145</span><title>況</title>	<p>This key word is a connector used to link contrasting phrases and sentences together with much the same flavor as the English phrase but of course。 Just picture yourself ready to go off on your first date as a teenager、 and having your mother grill y...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況 きょう">キョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況">況</a>
<span id = "number">146</span><title>河</title>	<p>The character in this frame represents a step up from the stream we met in frame 127 川； it is a full－sized river。 The water to the left tells us what we are dealing with、 and the can at the right tells us that our “little engine that could”...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 か">カ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河かわ">河かわ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河">河</a>

<span id = "number">161</span><title>火</title>	<p>Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames、 this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see。 It no longer makes a good pictograph、 but I invite y...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 か">カ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火ひ">火ひ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火ほ">火ほ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火">火</a>
<span id = "number">162</span><title>炎</title>	<p>A fire belongs in the hearth、 not over it。 When the fire spreads to the rest of the house、 we have an inflamed house。 And as with any inflammation—including those that attack our bodies—the danger is always that it might spread if not checked...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 えん">エン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎ほのお">炎ほのお</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎">炎</a>
<span id = "number">163</span><title>煩</title>	<p>The existential condition of anxiety that arises from the inevitable frustration of our worldly passions is contained in this character。 The head is set afire、 causing deep torment of spirit （and a whopper of a headache）。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 はん">ハン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 ぼん">ボン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩わずら－う">煩わずら－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩わずら－わす">煩わずら－わす</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩">煩</a>
<span id = "number">164</span><title>淡</title>	<p>The primitives in this kanji read： water 。 。 。 inflammation。 Taking inflammation in its medical sense、 the first water－related inflammation that pops into mind is dehydration、 the principal symptom of which is that it makes one shrivel up...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡 たん">タン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡あわ－い">淡あわ－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡">淡</a>
<span id = "number">165</span><title>灯</title>	<p>Since it is very hard to read by the fireplace without going blind from the flickering of the flames or burning up from the heat、 our ancestors invented a way to nail down a bit of that fire、 just enough to light up the text of their evening newspape...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 とう">トウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯ひ">灯ひ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯">灯</a>
<span id = "number">166</span><title>畑</title>	<p>Looking at the primitives、 a fireplace and a rice field、 we find the essential ingredients for a farm： a warm hearth to sit by at night、 and a well－plowed field to grow one’s crops in by day。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑はた">畑はた</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑はたけ">畑はたけ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑">畑</a>
<span id = "number">167</span><title>災</title>	<p>Of all of nature’s disasters、 this kanji picks out two of the worst： floods and fires。 To recall the disposition of the elements、 think of nature’s solution to nature’s own problem： a great flood pouring down over a great forest fire。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災 さい">サイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災わざわ－い">災わざわ－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災">災</a>

<span id = "number">169</span><title>点</title>	<p>If you look into the flickering of a fire for a long time and then turn aside、 you will see spots before your eyes。 Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before—as least as far as I know、 they didn’t—imagine using those spots as a tech...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点 てん">テン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点">点</a>
