<span id = "number">172</span><title>漁</title>	<p>To the story we have just made about fish、 this kanji for the profession of fishing adds yet another element before the others： namely the water、 where the fish was happily at home before being caught、 disemboweled、 and eaten。 Be sure to get ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 ぎょ">ギョ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 りょう">リョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁">漁</a>
<span id = "number">173</span><title>里</title>	<p>That’s right—a ri。 Don’t bother looking it up in your English dictionary； it’s a Japanese word for measuring distances。 One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2。5 miles。 The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used。 Atop we see the rice...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 り">リ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里さと">里さと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里">里</a>
<span id = "number">174</span><title>黒</title>	<p>Like most things electrical、 a computer、 too、 can overheat。 Just imagine flames pouring out of it and charring the keyboard、 the monitor、 and your desk a sooty black color。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 こく">コク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒くろ">黒くろ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒くろ－い">黒くろ－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒">黒</a>
<span id = "number">175</span><title>墨</title>	<p>Besides meaning black ink、 this kanji also appears in the word for an inked string that is pulled taut and snapped to mark a surface、 much the same as one might used a chalked string。 Here it is used to mark off the dirt with black lines for a foot...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 ぼく">ボク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨すみ">墨すみ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨">墨</a>
<span id = "number">176</span><title>鯉</title>	<p>These are the same carp you see in Japanese “carp streamers。” Only here we find a small home computer or two strung on the line by a father anxious for his son not only to have the courage and determination of a carp swimming upstream、 but also t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉">鯉</a>
<span id = "number">177</span><title>量</title>	<p>Think of quantity as having to do with measuring time and distance、 and the rest is simple： you have a quantity of time in the new day that begins with nightbreak、 and a quantity of distance in the rural ri。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量 りょう">リョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量はか－る">量はか－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量">量</a>
<span id = "number">178</span><title>厘</title>	<p>No doubt you will find it in your heart to forgive me for forcing yet another Japanese word on you in this frame。 It is not the last time it will happen in this book、 but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary。 One rin is equ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘 りん">リン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘">厘</a>
<span id = "number">179</span><title>埋</title>	<p>When we speak of burying something （or someone、 for that matter）、 we usually mean putting them under ground。 Only here、 we are burying our beloved computer that has served us so well these past years。 Behind us a choir chants the “Dies ir...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋 まい">マイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋う－める">埋う－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋う－まる">埋う－まる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋う－もれる">埋う－もれる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋">埋</a>
<span id = "number">180</span><title>同</title>	<p>The primitives given are one and mouth under a hood。 Take the key word to connote the sameness that characterizes the life in a community of monks。 They all have the same habits、 including the “habit” they wear on their backs。 Here we see the...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同 どう">ドウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同おな－じ">同おな－じ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同">同</a>
<span id = "number">181</span><title>洞</title>	<p>The key word den refers to an animal lair hollowed out in the side of a mountain。 Now if we keep to the image of the monas－ tic life as an image for same、 we can picture a den of wild beasts dressed up in habits and living the common life in a moun...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 どう">ドウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞ほら">洞ほら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞">洞</a>
<span id = "number">182</span><title>胴</title>	<p>The word trunk refers to the part of the body that is left when you have “truncated” all the limbs。 I can hardly think of any reason for doing so、 unless one were lumberjacking corpses and needed to have them all properly pruned and made the same...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴 どう">ドウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴">胴</a>
<span id = "number">183</span><title>向</title>	<p>Something referred to as “over yonder” is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight—like a wee drop in the distance—and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out。 Hence this kanji begins with a d...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向む－く">向む－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向む－ける">向む－ける</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向む－かう">向む－かう</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向む－こう">向む－こう</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向">向</a>

<span id = "number">185</span><title>字</title>	<p>Here is the character for character itself。 Not just kanji、 but any written character from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet。 It shows us simply a child in a house。 But let us take advantage of the double meaning of the key word t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 じ">ジ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字あざ">字あざ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字">字</a>

<span id = "number">189</span><title>宵</title>	<p>As the key word hints、 the kanji in this frame refers to the late evening or early morning hours、 well after one should be in bed asleep。 It does this by picturing a house with a candle in it。 The reason is obvious： whoever is living there is ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵よい">宵よい</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵">宵</a>
<span id = "number">190</span><title>安</title>	<p>To be told that the place of the woman is in the house may not sit well with modern thought、 but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age。 So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of relaxing after a hard...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安 あん">アン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安やす－い">安やす－い</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安">安</a>
<span id = "number">191</span><title>宴</title>	<p>To carry on from the last frame、 we note the entire day of work that comes between a woman and her house in preparing for a dinner banquet、 pictorially “interrupting” her relaxation。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴 えん">エン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴">宴</a>
<span id = "number">192</span><title>寄</title>	<p>Let the idea of drawing near suggest something dangerous or eerie that one approaches with fear and trembling。 Here we see a strange house—perhaps the haunted House of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized、 or the enchanted Gingerbread House that...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄 き">キ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄よ－る">寄よ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄よ－せる">寄よ－せる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄">寄</a>
<span id = "number">193</span><title>富</title>	<p>Here we have the original character on which the primitive element for wealth is based。 In keeping with the story introduced back then、 note how all the wealth is kept under the roof of the same house。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 ふ">フ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 ふう">フウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富と－む">富と－む</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富とみ">富とみ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富">富</a>
<span id = "number">194</span><title>貯</title>	<p>To avoid confusing this frame with the last one、 try to think of savings as actual money。 The only diff erence is that our currency is not paper bills but shells、 a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations。 The nail under the roof of ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯 ちょ">チョ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯">貯</a>
<span id = "number">195</span><title>木</title>	<p>Here we see a pictograph of a tree、 showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke。 The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots。 Although it may look similar at first si...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 ぼく">ボク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 もく">モク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木き">木き</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木こ">木こ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木">木</a>
<span id = "number">196</span><title>林</title>	<p>Learn this frame in connection with the next one。 A grove is a small cluster of trees。 Hence the simple reduplication of the kanji for tree gives us the grove。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 りん">リン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林はやし">林はやし</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林">林</a>
<span id = "number">197</span><title>森</title>	<p>A forest is a large expanse of trees、 or “trees、 trees everywhere、” to adopt the expression we used back in frames 22 and 23。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 しん">シン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森もり">森もり</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森">森</a>

<span id = "number">203</span><title>杏</title>	<p>Since apricots can be eaten just as they fall from the trees、 picture this mouth agape at the bottom of a tree （just as the elements have it）、 waiting for apricots to fall into it。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏">杏</a>

<span id = "number">208</span><title>村</title>	<p>The character for village was associated with rice fields （frame 92 町）。 That for town、 a step up on the evolutionary path to cities、 shows a circle of trees glued together to measure off the confines of a town。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 そん">ソン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村むら">村むら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村">村</a>

<span id = "number">240</span><title>黙</title>	<p>Oddly enough、 the character for silence shows us a black chihuahua。 Actually、 the cute little critter’s name is Darkness、 as I am sure you remember from the famous song about silence that begins、 “Hello、 Darkness、 my old friend。…”...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙 もく">モク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙だま－る">黙だま－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黙">黙</a>

<span id = "number">243</span><title>狩</title>	<p>One of the worst problems you have to face when you go hunting is to guard your take from the wild dogs。 If you imagine yourself failing at the task、 you will probably have a stronger image than if you try to picture yourself succeeding。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩 しゅ">シュ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩か－る">狩か－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩か－り">狩か－り</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狩">狩</a>

<span id = "number">256</span><title>玉</title>	<p>Note the drop here in the king’s scepter、 which is exactly what you would expect it to be： a precious jewel handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power。  As a primitive、 we can use this to mean either jewel or ball。 When it ap...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉 ぎょく">ギョク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉たま">玉たま</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/玉">玉</a>
<span id = "number">257</span><title>宝</title>	<p>Every house has its treasure、 as every thief knows only too well。 While the things we treasure most are usually of sentimental value、 we take the original sense of the term treasure here and make it refer to jewels kept in one’s house。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝 ほう">ホウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝たから">宝たから</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宝">宝</a>
<span id = "number">258</span><title>珠</title>	<p>Take care to keep the meaning of this kanji distinct from that for jewel。 Think of the most enormous pearl you have ever seen、 a great vermilion－colored ball sitting on your ring—and mak－ ing it extremely difficult to move without falling over ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠 しゅ">シュ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/珠">珠</a>
<span id = "number">259</span><title>現</title>	<p>Do not think of a “gift” here、 but of the present moment、 as distinct from the future and the past。 The kanji gives us a ball in which we see the present—obviously a crystal ball that enables us to see things going on at the present in farawa...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現 げん">ゲン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現あらわ－れる">現あらわ－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現あらわ－す">現あらわ－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/現">現</a>
<span id = "number">260</span><title>狂</title>	<p>A lunatic is literally one driven mad by the light of the moon、 and the most famous of the “looneys” are the legendary lycanthropes or “wolfmen。” Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon、 sometimes it is permanent。 In t...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂 きょう">キョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂くる－う">狂くる－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂くる－おしい">狂くる－おしい</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/狂">狂</a>
<span id = "number">261</span><title>皇</title>	<p>An emperor、 as we all know、 is a ruler—something like a king but higher in status。 The white bird perched above the king、 elevating him to imperial heights、 is the messenger he sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special fa...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇 おう">オウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皇">皇</a>
<span id = "number">262</span><title>呈</title>	<p>The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word with the line from the nursery rhyme about 4 and 20 blackbirds baked in a pie： “Wasn’t this a dainty dish to set before the king？” If we think of display in terms of that ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈 てい">テイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呈">呈</a>
<span id = "number">263</span><title>全</title>	<p>Wholeness suggests physical and spiritual health、 “having your act together。” The kanji－image for wholeness depicts being “king under your own umbrella、” that is、 giving order to your own life。 I know it sounds terribly abstract、 bu...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全 ぜん">ゼン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全まった－く">全まった－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全すべ－て">全すべ－て</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/全">全</a>
<span id = "number">264</span><title>栓</title>	<p>Here we think of plug in the sense of a cork or stopper used to seal the mouth of a bottle、 water faucet、 or something with liquid running out of it。 Forgetting the abstract picture of the former frame、 let us work with all the primitive units：...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓 せん">セン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栓">栓</a>
<span id = "number">265</span><title>理</title>	<p>We first referred to this character back in frame 173 里、 to which you might want to return to have a peek。 The image of logic we are given is something like a central jewel in a computer、 like the jewels in old clocks that keep them running smoot...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理 り">リ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/理">理</a>
<span id = "number">266</span><title>主</title>	<p>“A man’s home is his castle、” goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was lord of the household。 Fundamentally、 it means only that every one of us is a bit （or drop） of a king in our own environment。 As for the positionin...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主 しゅ">シュ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主 す">ス</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主ぬし">主ぬし</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主おも">主おも</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/主">主</a>
<span id = "number">267</span><title>注</title>	<p>Picture pouring water from a lighted candlestick。 What could be more ridiculous、 or simpler、 as a way to recall this kanji？</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注 ちゅう">チュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注そそ－ぐ">注そそ－ぐ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/注">注</a>
<span id = "number">268</span><title>柱</title>	<p>The pillar referred to here is the wooden beam that stands at the entrance to a traditional Japanese house。 Carve it in imagination into the shape of a gigantic candlestick and your work is done。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱 ちゅう">チュウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱はしら">柱はしら</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柱">柱</a>
<span id = "number">269</span><title>金</title>	<p>If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write、 I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows。 Anyway、 we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金 きん">キン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金 こん">コン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金かね">金かね</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金かな">金かな</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/金">金</a>
<span id = "number">270</span><title>銑</title>	<p>Pig iron refers to iron in the crude form in which it emerges from the smelting furnaces。 Of all the various forms metal can take、 this one shows us metal before it has been refined。 Imagine two photographs labeled “before” and “aft er” to ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銑">銑</a>
<span id = "number">271</span><title>鉢</title>	<p>Let bowl suggest a large and heavy golden bowl into which you are throwing all the books you own to mash them into pulp、 for some outrageous reason you will have to think up your self。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢 はち">ハチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢 はつ">ハツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鉢">鉢</a>
<span id = "number">272</span><title>銅</title>	<p>Picture an order of monks serving as chaplains for the police force。 Their special habit、 made of protective metal、 is distinguished by a row of copper buttons just like the “cops” they serve。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅 どう">ドウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/銅">銅</a>
<span id = "number">273</span><title>釣</title>	<p>The character we learned for fishing （frame 172 漁） refers to the professional、 net－casting industry、 while the angling of this character refers to the sport。 The odd thing is that your angling rod is a golden ladle which you are using to sc...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣 ちょう">チョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣つ－る">釣つ－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釣">釣</a>
<span id = "number">274</span><title>針</title>	<p>In frame 10 十 we referred ahead to this full character from which the primitive for needle （on the right） derives。 Since we already expect that needles are made of metal、 let us picture a set of solid gold darning needles to complete the kanji。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針 しん">シン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針はり">針はり</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/針">針</a>

<span id = "number">279</span><title>辻</title>	<p>Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10 十、 as the pictograph of a cross、 and set it on a road to create a “crossing。”</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/辻">辻</a>
<span id = "number">280</span><title>迅</title>	<p>Here we see a crossing in the form of a barbed fishhook、 suggesting a swift er alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the “cloverleaf” design used on superhighways in the United States。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅 じん">ジン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/迅">迅</a>
<span id = "number">281</span><title>造</title>	<p>Think of creating as making something out of nothing。 Then recall how the way of revelation laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God created the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造 ぞう">ゾウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造つく－る">造つく－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/造">造</a>

<span id = "number">283</span><title>逃</title>	<p>When escaping from something or someone、 one always feels as if one is not going fast enough、 like a turtle on an expressway。 （Since the turtle is on the road and not on the left 、 it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 235 兆。）</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃 とう">トウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃に－げる">逃に－げる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃に－がす">逃に－がす</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃のが－す">逃のが－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃のが－れる">逃のが－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逃">逃</a>

<span id = "number">288</span><title>軌</title>	<p>Combine the primary and secondary meanings of this key word to form your story。 Begin with the car whose tires get caught in a rut and spin without going anywhere。 Then go on to the baseball team who can’t win a game because it has fallen into a ru...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌 き">キ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/軌">軌</a>
<span id = "number">289</span><title>輸</title>	<p>On the left we see a vehicle used for transport。 On the right、 we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out。 The first three strokes、 you will remember、 are the primitive for meeting。 Below it we see the elements for flesh and saber...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸 ゆ">ユ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輸">輸</a>

<span id = "number">300</span><title>冗</title>	<p>Picture a weather vane beneath a regal crown、 spinning round and round。 It is not only superfluous but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗 じょう">ジョウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/冗">冗</a>

<span id = "number">302</span><title>輝</title>	<p>Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the ray of light to the left 。 Now add the glittering chariot that is emitting those rays and you have radiance。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝 き">キ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝かがや－く">輝かがや－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/輝">輝</a>

<span id = "number">305</span><title>夢</title>	<p>To have a dream after going to bed is really the crown to a perfect evening。 The flower petals over the eyes （instead of the “sand” that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning） only confirms the image of a pleasant ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢 む">ム</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢ゆめ">夢ゆめ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夢">夢</a>

<span id = "number">320</span><title>吉</title>	<p>Here we see a samurai standing on a street with an open mouth、 which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for good luck。  As a primitive、 we shall take this shape to mean an aerosol can、 from the mouth and the very tightly－fitting lid...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉 きち">キチ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉 きつ">キツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吉">吉</a>
<span id = "number">321</span><title>壮</title>	<p>Robust is seen as a turtle turned samurai。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮 そう">ソウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/壮">壮</a>
<span id = "number">322</span><title>荘</title>	<p>The villa pictured here is filled with exotic flowers at every turn、 and has a pair of turtle－samurai standing before its gates。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘 そう">ソウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/荘">荘</a>
<span id = "number">323</span><title>売</title>	<p>A samurai、 out of a job、 is going door－to－door selling little windup crowns with human legs that run around on the looking like headless monarchs。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売 ばい">バイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売う－る">売う－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売う－れる">売う－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/売">売</a>
<span id = "number">324</span><title>学</title>	<p>The child in the little red schoolhouse is there for one reason only： to study。 Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that study is one thing and learning quite another again。 In the kanji、 too、 the character for le...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学 がく">ガク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学まな－ぶ">学まな－ぶ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/学">学</a>
<span id = "number">325</span><title>覚</title>	<p>The idea of memorizing things is easily related to the schoolhouse； and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book、 the idea that memorizing involves seeing things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two ...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚 かく">カク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚おぼ－える">覚おぼ－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚さ－ます">覚さ－ます</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚さ－める">覚さ－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覚">覚</a>
<span id = "number">326</span><title>栄</title>	<p>The botanical connotations of the word flourish （to bud and burst into bloom、 much as a tree does） are part of the ideal of the schoolhouse as well。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄 えい">エイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄さか－える">栄さか－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄は－え">栄は－え</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄は－える">栄は－える</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/栄">栄</a>
<span id = "number">327</span><title>書</title>	<p>The sage talks rapidly with his tongue wagging in his mouth、 while the brush of the scribe runs apace to write down the master’s words。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書 しょ">ショ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書か－く">書か－く</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/書">書</a>
<span id = "number">328</span><title>津</title>	<p>Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks、 the All－Merciful took its brush and drew little inlets of water where the hapless creatures might seek shelter。 And so it is that we have havens。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津 しん">シン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津つ">津つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/津">津</a>
<span id = "number">329</span><title>牧</title>	<p>When it is time to breed new cattle、 the bull is usually willing but the cow is often not。 Thus the taskmaster to the right forces the cow into a compromising position、 so to speak、 so that she and her mate can breed。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧 ぼく">ボク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧まき">牧まき</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牧">牧</a>
<span id = "number">330</span><title>攻</title>	<p>The special craft of successful taskmasters is their ability to remain constantly on the aggressive、 never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter－aggression。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻 こう">コウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻せ－める">攻せ－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/攻">攻</a>
<span id = "number">331</span><title>敗</title>	<p>The taskmaster is acknowledging the failure of a clam to make the grade in some marine school or other。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗 はい">ハイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗やぶ－れる">敗やぶ－れる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敗">敗</a>
<span id = "number">332</span><title>枚</title>	<p>English counts thin、 flat objects、 like bed linen and paper、 in sheets。 The kanji does this with a taskmaster whipping a tree into producing sheets against its will。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚 まい">マイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枚">枚</a>
<span id = "number">333</span><title>故</title>	<p>Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck、 happenstance is the oldest taskmaster we know。 It nearly always has its way。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故 こ">コ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故ゆえ">故ゆえ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/故">故</a>
<span id = "number">334</span><title>敬</title>	<p>Standing in awe of someone、 you get self－conscious and may try to speak in flowery phrases out of veneration or fear。 The task master at the right is drilling you in the practice of your “honorifics。”</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬 けい">ケイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬うやま－う">敬うやま－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敬">敬</a>
<span id = "number">335</span><title>言</title>	<p>Of all the things we can do with our mouth、 speech requires the greatest distinctness and clarity。 Hence the kanji for say has four little sound－waves、 to show the complexity of the task。  This kanji、 which appears often as a primitive、 can...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言 げん">ゲン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言 ごん">ゴン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言い－う">言い－う</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言こと">言こと</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/言">言</a>
<span id = "number">336</span><title>警</title>	<p>Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements。 The idea of being admonished for something already sets up a superior－inferior relationship between you and the perso...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警 けい">ケイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/警">警</a>
<span id = "number">337</span><title>計</title>	<p>Words and a meter’s needle combine to form the sense of plot： to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計 けい">ケイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計はか－る">計はか－る</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計はか－らう">計はか－らう</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/計">計</a>
<span id = "number">338</span><title>獄</title>	<p>Although we did not make note of it at the time、 the kanji for dog is also a low－grade term for a spy。 And later （frame 1414 犯） we will meet another association of criminals with dogs。 The prison here depicts a pack of wild dogs （the long...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄 ごく">ゴク</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/獄">獄</a>
<span id = "number">339</span><title>訂</title>	<p>After completing the first draft 、 you revise it by nailing down your words and “hammering” them into shape。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂 てい">テイ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訂">訂</a>
<span id = "number">340</span><title>討</title>	<p>Words spoken to chastise us stick to us like glue in a way no other words can。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討 とう">トウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討う－つ">討う－つ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/討">討</a>
<span id = "number">341</span><title>訓</title>	<p>The personalism connoted by the word instruction、 as opposed to “teaching” or “discipline、” suits the picture here of words guiding one’s progress like the gentle flowing of a stream。 Even the etymology of the word instruction suggests th...</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓 くん">クン</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/訓">訓</a>
<span id = "number">342</span><title>詔</title>	<p>The imperial edict、 spoken with the force of unquestionable law、 is made up of words intended to seduce the masses—be it through fear or respect—to follow obediently。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔 しょう">ショウ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔みことのり">詔みことのり</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詔">詔</a>
<span id = "number">343</span><title>詰</title>	<p>A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as “packed。” The character sees the words as sealed tightly inside an aerosol can。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰 きつ">キツ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰つ－める">詰つ－める</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰つ－まる">詰つ－まる</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰つ－む">詰つ－む</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詰">詰</a>
<span id = "number">344</span><title>話</title>	<p>That the words of the tongue should come to mean a tale is clear from the etymology： a tale is something “talked、” not something read from a book。</p><br><br><title>Onyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話 わ">ワ</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話 "></a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話 "></a><br><br><title>Kunyomi</title><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話はな－す">話はな－す</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話はなし">話はなし</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/話">話</a>
